dialogues.text: Virginia stands in the doorway, staring at her sleeping children. Rachel opens her eyes and looks at her mother.  118. EXT. EMILY’S HOUSE - DAWN Edward walks the path towards Thomas and the waiting limo.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're a bundle of sticks, you and I, be it in this world or the one that follows. I will be forever grateful for the joy your life has brought to mine. Thomas opens the car door for him.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: So that’s your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (emotional) Yup.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Pretty. Edward looks angry. Thomas waits for the rebuke. Instead, Edward pats him on the shoulder before climbing into the car. Thomas looks back at the house as the lights go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward pulls the list out of his pocket. With the red pen he crosses out: “KISS THE MOST BEAUTIFUL WOMAN IN THE WORLD.”

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your friend always... Carter. Edward lowers the window and looks out at the painted dawn sky as the limo drives away. He stares for several moments then closes his eyes and listens...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. My name is Edward Cole and I’m not much of a storyteller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward is in his business suit again. His game face on.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I’m a business man, a good one. I run hospitals. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We take sick people and make them well again. Sometimes we succeed and sometimes we fail, but we’re getting better at it every day... I started out with nothing but cold ambition, and over the years my company grew until I had everything I ever wanted... I know now that-- I know now that I was never a wealthy man until my best friend came into my life...and from this incredible turnout, it only verifies the fact that Carter was truly the richest man I know. CAMERA TRACKS until we’re behind Edward revealing his audience of nearly a THOUSAND MOURNERS filling every last inch of the room including Carter’s family who sit in the front row. Familiar faces in the crowd include Manny, Holcomb, Nurse Shing, parents and players of the soccer team, etc.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what most people say at these things, so I’1l just tell you what I think Carter would want you to know. He’s dead and I still can’t shut him up... He loved his children more than his own heart. He loved his wife more than his own soul. He took the long way home but he made it back and you took him in and made him whole again and you will never know how grateful he was. His eyes move from the family to Thomas who stands against the wall with Emily and her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (taking out the Bucket List) We saw the world together. Pretty amazing when you think that only nine months ago we were strangers... He saved my life, and he knew it before I did. With the pen, he crosses out: “HELP A COMPLETE STRANGER FOR THE GOOD.” Beneath it, the last remaining task lies unfulfilled: “LISTEN TO THE MOUNTAIN AND BE HEARD.” Slowly, the words on the page--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the climber from the opening scene finally arrives at the peak.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Carter gave me a book once. It was about a man who knew a thing or two about the world. The climber walks over to a flat stone and lifts it onto its side. He removes his gloves revealing a wedding ring on his left hand. EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) The man said: “Learn as if you were going to live forever. Live as if you were going to die tomorrow.” His hands lift to his face, removing the oxygen mask and hood revealing THOMAS. He reaches down and lifts A FROZEN CHOCK FULL O’ NUTS CAN from its resting place in the hole beneath the rock. He wipes off a section of frost with his thumb revealing: A PHOTOGRAPH taped to the can -- Carter and Virginia at their second wedding surrounded by their family. Thomas sets the can on the snow then opens his backpack and reaches down to the bottom-- EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) Tomorrow comes for all of us. --and removes A SECOND CHOCK FULL 0’ NUTS CAN which he places on the ground next to the first. EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) It’s what we do in-between that makes us who we are. CLOSE ON A NEWER PHOTOGRAPH; taped to the second coffee can. It’s Edward. He’s old and grey.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Edward Perriman Cole died in May. It was a Sunday, in the afternoon, and there wasn’t a cloud in the sky... CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal that he’s closely surrounded by Thomas, Emily and their THREE CHILDREN, hands intertwined with--  121. --Carter’s grandchildren, each of whom stands with their parents and Virginia. One family. Edward is smiling like we’ve never seen.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was seventy-nine years old. Finally, Thomas deposits both cans into the hole beneath the rock. CARTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Even now, I can’t claim to understand the measure of a life, but I can tell you this... Thomas replaces the rock over the coffee cans.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know that when he died his eyes were closed, and his heart was open... I know that he could hear the mountain... THE CAMERA lingers on the rock for a moment then tilts up to reveal the breathtaking view of the entire world below. CARTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) And I know the mountain heard him in return. THE END.
